title: A Metal Block

children.value:
A metal block of mass 
$\vari{m}$
 rests on a rough wooden surface. A thread is attached to the right side of the block and a tension is applied to cause it to move. The motion is opposed by a constant frictional force 
$\vari{F_r}$
 between the block and the surface.

answer.value: Figure 1 is a diagram showing all of the forces acting on the block:

children.value: Draw a diagram to show all the forces on the block immediately after motion commences.

When the tension in the thread is 
$\vari{T}$
, the acceleration of the block is measured to be 
$\vari{a}$
. Calculate the new acceleration, 
$\vari{a_n}$
, if the tension is increased to 
$\vari{\frac{5}{4}T}$
.

answer.value:
The block will accelerate up to a maximum speed 
$\valuedef{u_{max}}{a_{n}t}{}$
, which comes from 
$\valuedef{v}{u + at}{}$
 but where 
$\valuedef{u}{0}{m\,  s\sup {-1}}$
, 
$\valuedef{a}{a_{n}}{}$
, 
$\valuedef{t}{t}{}$
 and 
$\valuedef{v}{u_{max}}{}$
 which will occur as the string breaks and the block stops accelerating. After this point the only force acting to affect the block's motion is the friction (the normal reaction and the weight are perpendicular to the motion, so do not affect it), and the block will decelerate to a halt.

children.value:
With the tension of $\vari{\frac{5}{4}T}$ applied, the block accelerates from rest but after a time $\vari{t}$ the string breaks. Explain the subsequent motion of the block, and also show that it travels a total distance of

$\displaystyle s = \frac{1}{2} \left(a_{n} + \frac{a_{n}^{2}m}{F_{r}} \right)t^{2} $

from its initial position.

Given that 
$\valuedef{T}{400}{N,}$
$\valuedef{m}{100}{kg}$
, 
$\valuedef{t}{2}{s}$
 and 
$\valuedef{a}{0.1}{m\,  s\sup {-2}}$
, calculate the work done by the block after the string breaks.
